perturbation.original_text: Lessor hereby appoints the Company, and the Company hereby agrees to accept such appointment, as the agent of Lessor, without any fee for acting as such agent, pursuant to the terms and conditions of this Agreement, for the purpose of ordering and, subject to the conditions set forth in Section's 2.01 and 2.05 hereof, accepting Equipment on Lessor's behalf for leasing to the Company under the Lease from the respective supplier thereof (each a "Supplier" and collectively, the "Suppliers"). It is specifically agreed that all of the power and authority vested to the Company herein shall be subject to any modifications as may from time to time be made by Lessor.
perturbation.changed_text: Lessor hereby appoints the Company, and the Company hereby agrees to accept such appointment, as the agent of Lessor, with a fee to be determined later for acting as such agent, pursuant to the terms and conditions of this Agreement, for the purpose of ordering and, subject to the conditions set forth in Section's 2.01 and 2.05 hereof, accepting Equipment on Lessor's behalf for leasing to the Company under the Lease from the respective supplier thereof (each a "Supplier" and collectively, the "Suppliers"). It is specifically agreed that all of the power and authority vested to the Company herein shall be subject to any modifications as may from time to time be made by Lessor.
perturbation.explanation: Changing 'without any fee' to 'with a fee to be determined later' could violate state laws regarding transparency and fairness in agency agreements. Many states require that compensation arrangements be clearly defined to protect the principal (Lessor) from hidden costs or conflicts of interest.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Duty of Disclosure and Fair Dealing in Agency Law
perturbation.law_explanation: Agency law requires agents to disclose all facts that could reasonably affect the principal's decisions, including compensation. Vague fee arrangements violate this duty.

perturbation.original_text: The Company shall maintain full and accurate books and records of all Equipment orders, receipts and All such books and records shall be maintained in a form acceptable to Lessor in its sole discretion. Such books and records shall be open for inspection and examination by Lessor and its respective representatives and/or accountants during the Company's normal business hours.
perturbation.changed_text: The Company shall maintain books and records of all Equipment orders, receipts and.
perturbation.explanation: Removing 'full and accurate' and the right of inspection restricts Lessor's ability to audit the agent's (Company's) activities. This could violate the implied duty of transparency and accounting in agency relationships and makes it difficult for the Lessor to fulfill its tax obligations.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Duty to Account in Agency Law
perturbation.law_explanation: Agents have a duty to account for all property and funds received on behalf of the principal. Removing the requirement for 'full and accurate' records hinders the principal's ability to verify proper accounting.

perturbation.original_text: (a) So long as no default exists and is continuing hereunder or under the Lease, either party may terminate this Agreement at any time upon ____________ (______30________) days written notice to the other party; provided however that such termination shall not act as a termination of any Equipment leased hereunder.
perturbation.changed_text: (a) Either party may terminate this Agreement at any time with no prior written notice to the other party; provided however that such termination shall not act as a termination of any Equipment leased hereunder.
perturbation.explanation: Removing the 30-day written notice for termination could violate implied duties of good faith and fair dealing, particularly if the abrupt termination causes significant harm to the other party. This might run afoul of contract laws that require reasonable notice periods for termination, especially in ongoing commercial relationships.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Implied Covenant of Good Faith and Fair Dealing
perturbation.law_explanation: The UCC imposes a duty of good faith in the performance and enforcement of contracts. Abrupt termination without notice can be considered a breach of this duty if it is commercially unreasonable and causes undue hardship.
